name: Transition by Design
description: Oxford based architecture & design cooperative. Specialising in green architecture, Passivhaus, community-led housing, participatory design and meanwhile use.
network: CAG network, Co-ops UK, Oxford Co-op Meetups, NEON

name: The Children's Allotment
description:
We are a community group creating an inclusive outdoor education space for the local community in the East Ward Allotments on Cricket Rd. Our focus is on providing cooperative childcare, outdoor learning and growing for families and children.


 

.
network: CAG, Phoenix Education Trust's network

name: Tandem Collective
description:
Tandem Collective believes the arts have a powerful role to play in enacting positive change on social and environmental issues. Tandem has grown out of a network of committed volunteers who came together to create the first Tandem Festival in 2014. Tandem is now an organisation reaching beyond the festival to create and facilitate inspiring, nourishing and developmental events and activities throughout the year.

Tandem Collective manages a wide range of events and collaborative projects that fuse volunteering opportunities, workshops, talks and skill-sharing with creative mediums including music, art, theatre, literature, cinema and dance. Our key projects are Ethno England, Tandem Skills Camp, InTandem with…, InTandem Publications and Tandem Festival. Tandem facilitates collaborations between artists, researchers, activists and campaign groups on local, national and international scales.
network:
CAGs
http://www.powerful-thinking.org.uk
https://www.seasonforchange.org.uk
https://www.juliesbicycle.com
http://www.abingdon-witney.ac.uk

name: CAG Project
description: CAG Oxfordshire is a network of voluntary groups and community led businesses working together to improve the wellbeing of people and the environment within Oxfordshire.

name: Broken Spoke Bike Co-op
description: The Broken Spoke Bike Co-op is a community business that aims to create an open, inclusive, collaborative and environmentally aware fixing & cycling community in Oxford(shire) by enabling people from all backgrounds to fix and ride cycles.

name: Talking Shop
description:
We are a community volunteer group based at Sandford-on-Thames' Village Hall. 
We run a cafe, convenient shop & community activities in our bright airy space.
We've got car parking, a lovely garden and a gate straight into the playground. 
We also have a volunteer bike mechanic team ​& a Good Neighbour network who match up volunteers offering support, lifts, companionship, with residents in need.
network:
Community Action Groups (CAG) network
Oxfordshire Community Shops Network

name: Free West Papua Campaign
description:
The Free West Papua Campaign was launched in 2004 in Oxford, UK. We are a peaceful, public campaign, whose aim is very simple: to give the people of West Papua the freedom to choose their own destiny through a fair and transparent referendum – a freedom they have always been denied. We work with politicians of all parties, and also with other NGOs and campaign groups, both national and international, towards this aim.

We have no religious, party-political or corporate affiliations, and we are determinedly non-violent. Our funding comes from donations, the sale of merchandise, public fundraising events and occasional grants from charitable foundations.
network:
We have grown from being a volunteer organisation through to having permanent offices in Oxford (UK), The Hague (Netherlands), Port Moresby (Papua New Guinea) and Perth (Australia). We are a group of people from human rights, political and environmental backgrounds, a number of whom are West Papuans or have spent time in West Papua. Our leadership comes from West Papuan representatives internationally, and in West Papua itself.

For contact details of offices outside the UK please see our website: http://www.freewestpapua.org

name: Oxford Stand Up To Racism
address[a1]: We don't have a physical address
description: We are witnessing an unprecedented growth in racism, racist attacks and far right activity.  We aim to mobilse people in protests and campaigns against Islamophobia, antisemitism and racism.  We say Black Lives Matter and oppose the racist scapegoating of migrants and refugees.  We mobilise against fascists whenever they raise their heads.
network: We have support from local trade union organisations and work with other campaign groups in campaigns where we share the same aim.

name: East Oxford Famers' & Comunity Market
address[a1]: This is the address where the market is held
description:
East Oxford Farmers' & Community Market started in August 2006 and is a non-profit Community Benefit Society run by a committee and a group of volunteers.
The market is a provides food staples such as bread, eggs, milk, vegetables, cheese, meats, as well as dried foods, other food products, and a café. The market also provides refills for cleaning supplies as well as non food items such as jewellery, clothing, books, antiques, and plastic free products. Most food producers are from within 30 miles of Oxford and the market also includes local small businesses. The market is wheelchair accessible both inside and outside.
network: Oxford Community Markets - www.ocmarkets.org

name: Aspire Oxfordshire
description: Aspire is a multi-award-winning employment charity and social enterprise. We exist to help vulnerable people who are homeless, long-term unemployed, ex-offenders, people in recovery or those with poor mental well-being to move into the world of work. We give them work experience on our own enterprise businesses and the person-centred support they need to make their own lasting change.
network: Oxfordshire Social Entrepreneurship Partnership (OSEP), Oxfordshire Charity Leaders' Forum

name: Botley community fridge
description: The Botley community fridge is a fridge in St. P&P church, into which anyone can put food and from which anyone can take food.  Mostly the food is surplus food from supermarkets that is picked up by volunteers, and the food is taken by people in need including many rough sleepers.  It's a win-win: environmental and social.  There is shelving next to the fridge with non-perishables that are donated by several food banks, who see the fridge as serving the same clientele that they would normally serve.
network:
Oxfordshire Community Action Groups
Hubbub community fridge group

name: Leys community fridge
description: The Leys community fridge is a fridge in the Blackbird Leys community centre into which anyone can put food, and from which anyone can take food.  In practice, most of the food comes from one large supermarket, and is brought to the fridge by volunteers in their private cars.  The fridge provides fresh fruit, vegetables, bread/pastries, dairy products and eggs for free to residents of the most deprived estate in Oxford.  It is a win-win: it reduces food waste and provides food to people who can really use it.
network:
Community Action Group
Oxford City Council

name: Rose Hill and Iffley Low Carbon (RHILC)
description: Rose Hill and Iffley Low Carbon is a Community Action Group that works with others to reduce the carbon footprint of our area and to make it more sustainable. We have worked with the organisations in brackets to: install 190 solar panels on Rose Hill Community Centre (OCC: Oxford City Council), solar PV and battery storage on 76 social homes in Rose Hill (Bioregional and OCC),  solar PV and battery storage on Rose Hill Primary School (Low Carbon Hub), a cycle repair kit (Low Carbon Hub and OCC) and  we run local bike repair workshops (Broken Spoke). We work closely with Rose Hill Primary School to plant trees, conduct assemblies and facilitate education about climate change. We organise Repair Cafes where people can get electrical goods, clothes and bikes mended for free (in cooperation with Rose Hill Community Centre). Wa also organise regular talks, workshops and films to raise awareness of particular aspects of sustainability on One Planet Living principles. Over the past five years, we have thermally imaged over 150 houses to check where heat is leaking out and advise on economic ways to insulate homes (assisted by CAG, the Low Carbon Hub and Bioregional). We are about to cooperate with 'Cosy Homes Oxfordshire' in providing expert insulation advice for individual house-holders. We are also exploring the possibility of heating Rose Hill homes with waste heat from Sainsbury's cooling systems (through Bioregional and OCC).
network: We are a part of the Community Action Group (CAG) Network, through which we cooperate with other CAGs, in particular LEAF Florence Park, Low Carbon East Oxford, Low Carbon Oxford North, Low Carbon West Oxford, We are members of the Low Carbon Hub CIC and actively promote  their share offers in renewable energy (solar PV on schools and Sandford and Osney Lock Hydro). We recently had training in One Planet Living from Bioregional and we won funding for them to train the teachers at Rose Hill Primary School in One Planet Living principles. The City Council has been very supportive of our group over many initiatives. We are currently working with them on: 1)  fabric first, low carbon design standards for the new flats at The Oval 2) cycle racks in Iffley Village 3) a heat network using waste heat from Sainsbury's coolers. We participate in working parties with BBOWT at our local Rivermead Nature Reserve. We collaborated with Cyclox on our Cycling Festival in June 2018 and our petition for segregated, continuous  cycle lanes into the city centre (which gained 1986 signatures).

name: OSEP CIC
address[a1]: This is the registered office and not used as an office
description: OSEP is a support organisation for Social Enterprise and other organisations making positive social and environmental impact. It has been established as a Community Interest Company by local social entrepreneurs with the support of both Oxford universities and other key local and national stakeholders.
network: Member of Social Enterprise UK, working closely with other local orgs such as CAG and LCH etc

name: African Families in the UK (AFiUK) and WOW Space (Women Of the World)
description: A community Interest Company  offering Training, Information, Support, and Advocacy in Health, Social Care, and Education; to third culture British African children and their families.  These services are extended to other newly arrived migrant families.  We run periodic cross cultural parenting courses for parents, as well as a weekly Women's group offering training in healthy family relationships and female wellbeing targeting BAMER women.

name: Oxford wood Recycling
description:
Oxford Wood Recycling was established in 2005 as a social enterprise to address the sustainability issues surrounding wood waste management in the UK whilst providing employment opportunities for people facing disadvantages to re-enter the workplace. Today OWR is best known as an inspirational place to visit in Abingdon for reclaimed timber for DIY and other interesting finds. The organisation has consistently grown,  currently making 1800 wood waste collections a year and reclaiming 300 tonnes of wood for reuse. OWR is a provider of employment services and employment for people with disabilities.

.
network:
Member of the Community Wood Recycling Projects Network  (NCWRP)
Fellow of School for Social Entrepreneurs.
Disability Confident Employer

name: Oxford SU LGBTQ+ Campaign
address[a1]: We do not have a physical address
description:
The LGBTQ+ Campaign is the political campaigning arm of Oxford’s queer community. We frequently work alongside the Student Union, LGBTQ+ college reps, and the OU LGBTQ+ Society. We have officers for the majority of the specific identities and intersections of the LGBTQ+ umbrella. We are also keen to work with LGBTQ+ community activist groups based in Oxford. If this is you, please feel free to email us. 

Oxford SU LGBTQ+ Campaign takes a very active role in student life: We oversee the organisation of LGBTQ+ 101 workshops at approximately half of Oxford colleges. We engage in a broad range of events, including protests and demonstrations, engaging with the local community and hosting talks, panel discussions, round tables, social events, and photo campaigns. We also work with the University's and colleges' administration to improve the lives of LGBTQ+ students. 

One of Campaign’s current priorities is fighting transphobia and improving the living and working conditions of transgender students in Oxford. We have conducted a trans survey based on which we are working towards changing policies at both a university and college level to tackle hate speech both broadly and pertaining to specific LGBTQ+ identities.
Feel free to get in contact with us at lgbtq-chair@oxfordsu.ox.ac.uk or by messaging the Facebook page.

name: Oxford Human Rights Festival
description: The Oxford Human Rights Festival was started as a film festival in 2001 by Oxford Brookes students on the MA Development and Emergency Practice course. The aim of the festival is to raise awareness of human rights issues through the arts. It is now curated by students from across the university and the annual programme includes film and documentary screenings, lectures, workshops, exhibitions, and performances. All events take place at Oxford Brookes University, are free and open to everyone; students, staff and the wider Oxford community.
network: Partner of the International Human Rights Arts Festival in New York. https://ihraf.org/partners We also took part in this year's Oxford International Women's Festival.

name: Oxford City Council Co-operatives Champion
description: Oxford City Council appointed Cllr Richard Howlett to act as its Co-operatives Champion in January 2019. The ‘champion’ role is a way for non-executive cllrs to represent the council on areas about which they are passionate. Richard Howlett has worked in co-ops in the city for the past decade and is committed to the growth of the local co-op economy. He convened an ‘advisory group’ of local co-operators who sit around the role to give advice and support and to whom he is accountable.

name: Common Ground Café & Workspace
description:
Common Ground is a social enterprise pop-up café and workspace where people can stay as long as they like.  (Free wifi and power, but buy something to keep us afloat.)  
Our social purpose is to support student mental health by providing a relatively quiet space where people can come and just “be” on their own terms.  Less lonely than your room and more connected with society than the college library.  We have time to be friendly and welcoming.  
However, we “create community” and have morphed into a social space for this part of Jericho.
We host many different events in the evenings and for groups looking for somewhere to meet and have yoga twice a day too.
Everything is as sustainable as possible and is second hand, upcycled, made or donated.
network: We support groups with similar goals or aims, including social enterprise start-ups, repair café, student minds, etc.

name: Wolvercote Sunday Market
description: This is a small weekly market run by volunteers and held in a community-run pub. It offers local organic eggs, a range of organic vegetables and fruits (from local sources whenever possible), sourdough breads and cakes made from organic flour, plus (visiting the market at various intervals from fortnightly to monthly) other local products like jams, Italian and Greek foods, cured meats, knitted clothing, plants, etc., plus services such as the local councillors' surgery. The pub provides Sunday breakfast, teas and coffees, meanwhile.

name: Rose Hill Carpet Bowls and New Age Curling
description: Welcome to Rose Hill Carpet Bowls And New Age Curling. This meetup group is for those interested in carpet bowls and / or new age curling and would like to try out a new sport.

name: Communi-tea cafe
description: A friendly community cafe in Blackbird Leys serving breakfasts and tasty Caribbean food.

name: Communi-tea Cafe
description: Community Cafe in the centre of Blackbird Leys. Predominantly Caribbean food with some alternatives. Affordable Main meals, coffee and cakes, snacks.

name: Allsorts Rose Hill
description: Stay-and-play run by volunteers to support families with children under 5.
network: No

name: Campaign for Real Farming and Food Culture
address[a1]: no physical address - but I'm based in Wolvercote. So will OX2 do?
hours[SQ001comment]: all reasonable god given hours most days (though not after 6.00pm as a whole)
description:
The campaign exists to help create "convivial societies within a flourishing biosphere" by bringing about an agrarian renaissance based on the principals and practices of "Real Farming".  Real farming is defined as “Farming that is expressly designed to provide everyone everywhere with food of the highest quality, forever, without wrecking the rest of the world”. 
The campaign seeks to bring about the necessary changes along  four pathways: farm practice based on agroecology; the introduction of food sovereignty whereby individuals and communities have charge of their own food supply; economic democracy - essentially a tripartite mixed economy, with cooperation and social enterprise key drivers; and respect for traditional knowledge including attitudes towards ownership of land.
network: Loads!  eg Sustain the Alliance for Sustainable Food and Farming; the Pasture Fed Livestock Association, UK Food Group, the Landworkers' Alliance, the European Network for Access to Land, Land Justice. . .

name: Oxford SU Women’s Campaign
description: The women’s campaign is for all women (trans, cis, and intersex) and non-binary people, including those with complex gender identities who associate in some way with the term woman, as well as those who feel they experience structural misogyny. We organize a range of events from feminist discussion groups and panels to working on lobbying the university and collaborating on demonstrations. All our events are very welcoming and there’s no level of experience or knowledge required or expected to attend. We also hold regular open meetings where women and non-binary students are very welcome. These are a great opportunity for anyone outside our committee to bring ideas and suggestions to us. Our facebook page is the best place to keep up with what we’re doing, to get involved with our events, and to contact us with any inquiries or suggestions.
network: We are a part of the Oxford SU campaigns, which include WomCam, Class Act, CRAE, Disabilities Campaign, International Students, LGBTQ+, and SusCam

name: Oxford Poetry Library
address[a1]: We are a mobile, pedal-powered library with no fixed location, but run events all through the city. OX4 is where our admin/mailing address is.
description: Oxford Poetry Library aims to provide a space in Oxford for people to access and talk about poetry, discover new writing, and be platformed as local writers. As a library, we promote collective ownership, shared resources, and knowledge shared through collaboration in community spaces. It is free to join the library and anyone can borrow books, with no late fees or punishing fines for overdues. We operate out of a big custom-built purple cargo bike, peddling (and pedalling) our wares to farmers markets, festivals, and street events throughout the city for all sorts of people to discover all sorts of poetry. A lot of our work is focused on marginalized groups (such as young people, the homeless and vulnerably housed, and mental health charities), collaborating with other organizations to promote access to literature for people who might not otherwise have it. We also sell zines, books, and magazines created or produced locally and by Oxford writers, run regular events, workshops, and reading groups.
network: We are a Community Action Group, and work regularly with many other CAGs in our work, most regularly with the East Oxford Farmers and Community Market, South Oxford Community Market, and Flo's The Place in the Park. We also collaborate with Open House Oxford (a public living room and talking shop about housing and homelessness) on a weekly drop-in workshop, run occasional sessions at O'Hanlon House (a homelessness shelter) and The Gatehouse (a drop-in centre for vulnerably housed people and people facing homelessness). We have recently collaborated with Lost Words Oxfordshire on a crowdfunder campaign to get a copy of The Lost Words by Robert Macfarlane/Jackie Morris in every primary school in Oxfordshire.

name: Solidarity Economy Association
description: A not-for-profit that supports and promotes the solidarity economy - organisations, projects and people working to create a socially just and ecologically sustainable world.
network: Members of: Co-operatives UK, Co-operative College, RIPESS Europe, Global Justice Now. Regularly attend Oxford Co-ops Meet Up group. Based at Makespace Oxford.

name: Hempen
description: Hempen is a not for profit workers cooperative growing and producing organic hemp into goods for the benefit of people, community and planet.
network: Yes we are part of Co-ops UK, the Land Workers Alliance and the British Hemp Association.

name: Transition Chipping Norton
description: Sustainble community solutions - practical intiatives for a thriving, sustainable future for our town
network: Community Action Groups Oxfordshire, Transition Network

name: Open House
description: We’re a public talking shop on housing and homelessness. We like drinking tea, making new friends and talking to strangers about housing. We’re trying to get as many people as possible, especially those without a permanent home, involved in the decisions that are being made about how we house people in Oxford.
network: Oxford Homeless Movement, Community Action Groups, Women's Hope Forum

name: The Village - Childcare Collective
description: The Village is a collective of 15 families who care for one another's children - like a childcare "time bank". This offers free, flexible, trusted and community-based childcare to families.
network: We are under the umbrella of the Children's Allotment.

name: SOMA Housing Co-Operative Ltd
description: It is SOMA's intention to purchase land in order to establish a sustainable community which is made up of "social housing" with tenants living in self built eco homes which they have at an affordable rent. The co-op will also provided support structures that are required and which enable a disabled person to live independently and experience a healthier and more fulfilling life.

name: Banbury Community Action Group
address[a1]: We don't have a physical address
description:
Banbury Community Action Group was set up in 2013 to run free local community projects on food, waste, transport and energy.

We meet 1st Tuesday of the month at 4 Ale and Gin, Butchers Row, Banbury and occasionally other locations around the town.

There are always lots of projects on the go including our Community Edible Garden, Give or Take events and work in the Community Orchard.  We are always looking for new people to join us and get involved in a project or start a new one!
network: We are part of the Oxfordshire Community Action Groups Network

name: Tolhurst Organic Partnership
hours[SQ001comment]: "honesty box" Lin's VegShed at farm gate
hours[SQ002comment]: "honesty box" Lin's VegShed at farm gate
hours[SQ003comment]: "honesty box" Lin's VegShed at farm gate
hours[SQ004comment]: "honesty box" Lin's VegShed at farm gate
hours[SQ005comment]: "honesty box" Lin's VegShed at farm gate
hours[SQ006comment]: "honesty box" Lin's VegShed at farm gate
hours[SQ007comment]: "honesty box" Lin's VegShed at farm gate
description: Tolhurst Organic is a farm specialised in local fruit and veg. The food produced here is the product of an entire journey. The journey is one which deeply involves many people who come here, creates a model for Stockfree Organic farming, supports an idyllic rural lifestyle and provides soul food for those who work here and good food for ourselves and our families. Our aim is not to supply every family in the south but to farm with an emphasis on education and conservation. Our farming system not only helps to minimise harmful effects on the environment but feeds you and your family as well.
network: Thames Organic Growers, Organic Growers Alliance, Landworkers Alliance

name: Kindling Housing Co-operative
description: Kindling Housing Cooperative aims to provide a safe, secure, affordable and supportive environment for generations of politically and socially active individuals. We believe this is even more important at a time when other forms of housing are further out of reach. We aim to provide a productive living space for a diverse group of individuals and help to ensure the continuation of vital radical social and ecological projects for a more equal society. Through this project we are attempting to demonstrate and inspire a different way of living: taking decisions by consensus, taking control of our infrastructure, connecting to the community and ecosystem, whilst being practical, empathic, active and egalitarian.
network: We are part of the Radical Routes network (global network of fully mutual housing coops). In Oxford we are part of the Fairer Housing Network.

name: SHARE Oxford
description: SHARE Oxford aims to make sharing easier and to increase access to good quality things so that we may reduce consumption and waste, save money, save the environment, and feel good about it. We host Oxford’s Library of Things, which allows people to borrow instead of buy items needed only occasionally, like outdoor equipment, DIY tools, cooking implements, and more. We also run regular Repair Cafes where our volunteers fix your broken items to keep them in use for longer.
network: Library of Things movement and CAG Oxfordshire Network

name: Harwell Green Club
description: The Harwell Green Club is a forum for People on and off the Harwell Campus with a shared interest in a Low Carbon Sustainable Future. It aims to bring people of this mind together to share information, make new connections and exchange views, meeting informally the third Thursday of the month, and is open to all.
network: We are a network!

name: Dragonfly Housing Co-operative
description: Dragonfly is a Housing Co-operative with a mission to provide a fair-priced, democratically-controlled home, whilst encouraging its residents to contribute to various environmental and social justice campaigns. Dragonfly is a member of the Radical Routes network of radical co-operatives, whose members are also committed to working for positive social change. The network is made up mainly of housing co-operatives of various sizes (none with more than 17 members), a few workers co-ops and a couple of social centres.
network: Radical Routes

name: Oxford Wood Recycling
description: Oxford Wood Recycling was established in 2005 to address the sustainability issues surrounding wood waste management in the UK whilst providing employment opportunities for people facing disadvantages to re-enter the workplace. We collect unwanted wood from both commercial and domestic properties that may otherwise end up in landfill. Our reclaimed wood is then cleaned up and offered for sale or made into furniture in our Abingdon workshop - reducing waste and carbon emissions by recycling and up-cycling wood.
network: We are part of the Community wood Recycling Project network. We are also members of Social Enterprise UK, and OCVA, and the Plunkett foundation in Woodstock.

name: Agile Collective
description:
Agile Collective is an ethical digital agency and worker co-operative with an experienced team based in the UK and Italy. We work exclusively with organisations that have a positive impact in the world, and our clients are most often drawn from the charity, NGO, education and public sectors. We work with open source software and agile delivery methodologies and place a strong emphasis on user experience. Our core technology is the leading open source content management system (CMS), Drupal, but from time to time we also work with other open source platforms including Wordpress.
As a company with a conscience, we contribute to our communities, minimise our environmental impact, value fairness and transparency, and ensure sustainability in our working practices.
network: CoTech, a network of tech worker coops in the UK. The manifesto is at https://www.coops.tech/manifesto

name: Hand me on maternity, baby & toddler kit Oxford
description: We are an online community that share and pass on pre-loved maternity, baby and toddler clothes, toys and equipment for free.

name: Hand me on 3-8yrs kid's stuff Oxford
description: We are an online community that share and pass on pre-loved maternity, baby and toddler clothes, toys and equipment for free.

name: Low Carbon West Oxford
description: Low Carbon West Oxford (LCWO) was set up after the summer floods of 2007 by residents concerned about climate change and local flooding. It is a community-led initiative which aims to combat climate change by cutting their community’s carbon dioxide emissions by 80 % by 2050, encouraging residents to live more sustainably, and contributing to a more cohesive and resilient community. They seek to work in an inclusive manner and ensure that everyone who lives and works in the area has a chance to participate in and benefit from LCWO’s projects.
network:
We are part of a network with two local initiative, WOCORe and Osney Lock Hydro – read more about the West Oxford Model here: https://www.lowcarbonwestoxford.org.uk/the-west-oxford-model/
Formal network of CAGs - Community Action Groups - in Oxfordshire
Also part of various informal sub groups working on different particular issues
In addition, we work closely with others through Low Carbon Oxford's Oxford Green Week, Bioregional's One Planet Oxfordshire, Oxfordshire Together on Climate Change and with the Low Carbon Hub - and frequently partner with other groups and networks (both formal and informal) on particular events and topics.

name: South Oxford Farmers and Community Market
description: The South Oxford Farmers and Community Market (SOFACOMA) is a weekly market selling ethically-produced local, seasonal and/or organic food and non-food goods. We define ‘local’ as being produced within a 30-mile radius of Oxford; and ‘produced’ as containing a significant quantity of local ingredients and labour. The South Oxford Farmers and Community Market is an initiative of the Low Carbon South Oxford (LCSO) Sustainable Food Group which supports the promotion of local food as a way of helping to combat climate change by reducing the amount of carbon released in the transport of food over long distances.
network: Kind of. There is an Oxford Community Markets group but it is pretty dormant. We are part of the Low Carbon South Oxford group (also fairly dormant as a committee) which is a CAG member.

name: Oxford GreenPrint
hours[SQ001comment]: 12:00 – 14:00 or by arrangement outside these times
hours[SQ002comment]: 12:00 – 14:00 or by arrangement outside these times
hours[SQ003comment]: 12:00 – 14:00 or by arrangement outside these times
hours[SQ004comment]: 12:00 – 14:00 or by arrangement outside these times
hours[SQ005comment]: 12:00 – 14:00 or by arrangement outside these times
description: Oxford GreenPrint is a workers’ co-operative providing ethical, low impact printing to community groups, campaign groups, NGOs and businesses both in Oxford and across the UK. All their printing is done on recycled paper or card using renewable energy.

name: Abingdon Carbon Cutters
network: CAG and Transition Network.

name: Oxford Permaculture Picturehouse
description: Oxford Permaculture Picturehouse aims to bring people together around films in sympathy with permaculture, promoting permaculture messages and know-how, but most of all reinforcing the network of interested people. Films are usually screened on the 4th Monday of the month at the East Oxford Community Centre.

name: New Internationalist Publications Ltd
description: New Internationalist is a leading independent media organization dedicated to socially conscious journalism and publishing. They are an independent, not-for-profit media multi-stakeholder co-operative, owned by their workers and over 3,600 investors. They tell the stories that the mainstream media sidestep and offer a platform for the people living those stories. Their award-winning magazine, books and website set the agenda for a radically fairer future, promote global justice and campaign for the disadvantaged all over the world.

name: We Own It
description: We Own It’s mission is to end privatisation for good so that people come before profit. We believe public services should belong to all of us - whether that's the NHS, schools, water, energy, rail, Royal Mail, care work or council services. Our work focuses on two things: campaigning against privatisation, and making the case for public ownership.
network: We collaborate with campaigns to protect specific services, like Keep Our NHS Public, the Anti-Academies Alliance, etc. We don't duplicate their work, but amplify it when we can. We're also part of the New Economy Organisers Network and have benefitted from their spokesperson network training, press officer training, and organisation building workshops.

name: Project SOUP
description:
Since its inception in 2013, Project SOUP (Support Oxford's Upcoming Projects) has been committed to combatting local issues and being a driving force for change in the Oxford community. Project SOUP brings together the people behind new community project ideas and the people that want to help make them happen. Together they enable people to support local projects in an effective way via a simple, democratic vote over a delicious dinner, made from surplus food. 
They hold one soup-filling, heart-warming event per Oxford academic term. At each event, 3-4 local social action groups/charities are invited to speak about their work, ‘pitch’ an idea to try and persuade the audience for their vote. After all the votes have been counted, a winner is announced and all the money on the door and extra donations goes directly to them.
network:
Informal: 
•	Amy Kaherl's Movement (Who started the SOUP Movement in Detroit) - part of an online group of people who share updates/ stories etc
•	UK SOUP organisers - we share updates/resources through this 
Formal:
•	Part of Community Action Groups Oxfordshire (CAG)
•	Part of the Oxford Hub

name: Rose Hill Community Cupboard
description: Rose Hill Community Cupboard provides food and essential items to people who need it the most. They help people by serving a cuppa and a snack and sending them home with a loaf and a nutritious bag of fresh fruit and veg. Visitors can chat, colour and play games while waiting to choose some groceries at the drop-in centre at Rose Hill Methodist Church one afternoon a week.
network: We are served by the Food Bank.

name: Orinoco Scrapstore
description: Orinoco’s mission is to banish boredom and save the planet using creativity and play to inspire the reuse of materials. Over its 25 year history, Orinoco has saved lorry loads of interesting resources from ending up in landfill. Their Scrapstore in Headington sells scrap items for art, crafts, play and creative projects as well as new art materials, refurbished tools and DIY stuff. They collect suitable waste materials from businesses for potential reuse; accept usable garden and workshop tools; and hold a monthly ‘Swap Shop’ on the second Saturday of every month for usable household items people may no longer need or want.
network: We were - Reuseful UK were a charity the manager a scrap store network. They dissolved last week! And are being replaced by a website www.scrapstorenetwork.co.uk. which may be useful.

name: Oxfordshire Asian Women's Voice
description: Oxfordshire Asian Women's Voice was set up 7 months ago to provide support and advice to Asian women in their native language. We respond to the needs and requests from our members, providing support in a range of areas from learning new skills to accessing services and support against domestic violence.
